ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: So many. Developed my ability to think deeply and wade through some very challenging topics and readings.
I learned to think using a range of analytical methods in art history. The class made me step out of my comfort zone in that sense, and I'm so grateful for that!
I learned all about the different art historical disciplines and methodologies, and I learned how to really look at art through different lenses and with new, different perspectives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was great just the way it was, considering it was a virtual seminar. Just really wish I could have taken it in person.

A wonderful overview of art historical methods from Vasari to the modern movement to decolonize. Professor Barringer is fantastic and engaging professor, and his deep knowledge of and familiarity with the material always led to interesting anecdotes and great discussions, despite the online format. My only critique is that we didn't address approaches to aesthetic theory at all-- I would have liked to have read Burke, Reynolds, Hegel, etc.

The course does a great job of interrogating all of the methods we learn, so that we can learn to be critical of the approaches themselves. It spends a great amount of time on each different approach and builds knowledge that we could apply throughout the semester.

I think the only weakness of the course this semester was that it was over zoom, which of course could not be helped. I would have loved to engage with the art in real life in the museums and galleries of Yale, but since that could not happen this semester, the course was the best it could have possibly been.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think Professor Barringer did the absolute best that could have been done with the online format, as I know he wished we could have done things in person as well. The course was the best it could have been online!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes absolutely but it is not for the faint of heart or someone who is not willing to roll up their sleeves, do a LOT of reading and prepping for seminar, and wade through some challenging topics.

I would absolutely recommend this course to any History of Art major. Professor Barringer, especially, is an incredible professor. He is unwittingly hilarious, a wealth of knowledge, and so encouraging. I personally couldn't have imagined taking this course with anyone else.
Yes, definitely! Especially if you are a History of Art major.

Yes I would definitely recommend this course to another student! The course material was very interesting and Professor Barringer was enthusiastic and engaging. I looked forwards to this class every week!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
